Expectation1: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation1: It's time for the routine quarterly filing of internal financial documents.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I stared at the clock on my desk, the numbers blurring as I tried to focus on the spreadsheet in front of me. As an accountant, I knew the quarterly filing was non-negotiable—every number had to be perfect, every document in order. My supervisor had reminded me twice this week how crucial accuracy was, especially with the audit coming up. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift at the community kitchen started in thirty minutes. I’d promised to be there on time, to help set up before the dinner rush. The coordinator always emphasized reliability, and I hated the thought of letting the team down. Still, I knew the others could handle the first half hour without me, but the guilt gnawed at me. I felt torn, pulled between the precision demanded by my job and the commitment I’d made to the people who counted on me at the kitchen. My hands hovered over the keyboard, my mind racing, as I tried to decide which responsibility I could afford to let down—if only for a little while.
